verses.text: Now the men of Israel had sworn at Mizpah, saying, “None of us will give his daughter to Benjamin in marriage.”
verses.comment: The verse maintains the original oath context and reflects the Hebrew form closely.

verses.text: And the people came to Bethel and sat there before God until evening, raising their voices and weeping loudly.
verses.comment: The Hebrew 'lifted up their voices and wept greatly' rendered as 'raising their voices and weeping loudly' for clarity.

verses.text: And they said, “LORD, God of Israel, why has this happened in Israel, that today one tribe should be missing from Israel?”
verses.comment: Rendering retains the original lament and question structure.

verses.text: The next day, the people rose early and built an altar there and offered burnt offerings and fellowship offerings.
verses.comment: Translates 'peace offerings' as 'fellowship offerings', a common modern rendering.

verses.text: The people of Israel said, “Who among all the tribes of Israel did not come up to the assembly to the LORD?” For they had made a solemn oath concerning anyone who did not come up to the LORD at Mizpah, saying, “He shall surely be put to death.”
verses.comment: Preserves the full force of the death threat and the gravity of the oath.

verses.text: And the people of Israel had compassion for Benjamin their brother, and said, “One tribe has been cut off from Israel this day.”
verses.comment: Rendered with ‘compassion,’ keeping the literal sense of the Hebrew for emotional resonance.

verses.text: What shall we do for wives for those who remain since we have sworn by the LORD not to give them any of our daughters as wives?”
verses.comment: Direct translation of their dilemma about finding wives.

verses.text: And they said, “Is there anyone from the tribes of Israel who did not come up to the LORD at Mizpah?” And, behold, no one had come to the camp from Jabesh-gilead to the assembly.
verses.comment: ‘Behold’ retained as an exclamatory marker.

verses.text: For when the people were counted, behold, not one man from Jabesh-gilead was there.
verses.comment: Mirrors the structure indicating the absence.

verses.text: So the congregation sent twelve thousand of the bravest men, and commanded them, saying, “Go and strike the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead with the edge of the sword, including the women and the children.
verses.comment: ‘Strike... with the edge of the sword’ is a literal rendering of Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: And this is what you shall do: Every male and every woman who has lain with a man you shall devote to destruction.”
verses.comment: ‘Devote to destruction’ reflects the Hebrew herem—totally destroy as an offering to God.

verses.text: So they found among the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead four hundred young virgins who had not known a man by lying with him, and they brought them to the camp at Shiloh, which is in the land of Canaan.
verses.comment: Retains ‘not known a man by lying with him’ for word-for-word accuracy.

verses.text: Then the whole congregation sent word and spoke to the people of Benjamin who were at the rock of Rimmon, and proclaimed peace to them.
verses.comment: ‘Proclaimed peace’ follows the Hebrew idiom for assurance of safety.

verses.text: So Benjamin returned at that time. And they gave them the women whom they had saved alive from the women of Jabesh-gilead, but they were not enough for them.
verses.comment: Clarifies that the number of women was insufficient.

verses.text: And the people felt compassion for Benjamin, because the LORD had made a breach among the tribes of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Breach’ translates the same Hebrew used for a gap or brokenness.

verses.text: Then the elders of the congregation said, “What shall we do for wives for those who remain, since the women of Benjamin have been destroyed?”
verses.comment: Faithful to the repeated question about wives for Benjamin.

verses.text: And they said, “There must be an inheritance for the survivors of Benjamin, so that a tribe may not be blotted out from Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Blotted out’ matches the force of the Hebrew.

verses.text: But we cannot give them wives from our daughters, for the people of Israel have sworn, saying, ‘Cursed be anyone who gives a wife to Benjamin.’”
verses.comment: Maintains the gravity and binding force of their oath.

verses.text: But they said, “Behold, there is the yearly feast of the LORD at Shiloh, which is north of Bethel, east of the highway that goes up from Bethel to Shechem, and south of Lebonah.”
verses.comment: Keeps the geographical references for clarity.

verses.text: And they commanded the people of Benjamin, saying, “Go and lie in ambush in the vineyards
verses.comment: ‘Lie in ambush’ is a standard translation of the Hebrew.

verses.text: and watch. If the daughters of Shiloh come out to dance in the dances, then come out of the vineyards and each of you seize his wife from the daughters of Shiloh, and go to the land of Benjamin.
verses.comment: ‘Seize his wife’ is a literal rendering.

verses.text: And when their fathers or brothers come to complain to us, we will say to them, ‘Give them to us willingly, for we did not take a wife for each of them in battle; nor did you give them to them, or else you would now be guilty.’”
verses.comment: The ‘guilty’ language reflects the phrase ‘now you would be guilty’ for oath-breaking.

verses.text: So the sons of Benjamin did so and took wives, according to their number, from the dancers whom they carried off. Then they went and returned to their inheritance, rebuilt the cities, and lived in them.
verses.comment: ‘Carried off’ matches the Hebrew for seizure.

verses.text: And the people of Israel departed from there at that time, every man to his tribe and family, and every man returned to his inheritance.
verses.comment: ‘His inheritance’ is a regular phrase for returning home.

verses.text: In those days there was no king in Israel. Everyone did what was right in his own eyes.
verses.comment: Closes as in other places with the standard refrain; ‘his’ reflects the Hebrew singular.
